abstract.p: Letter by Rev Thomas J Paprocki, chancellor of Chicago archdiocese, objects to anti-Catholic imagery in art and other public derisions of Christianity (S)

block.p: Peter Steinfels's report on shocking examples of anti-Catholic imagery in modern art and on television (Beliefs column, May 16) is only a small sampling of the last bastion of tolerated bigotry in the United States. Such blatantly offensive incidents cannot be defended as artistic expression or disagreement with the Roman Catholic Church's teachings (letter, May 20).

Peter Steinfels's report on shocking examples of anti-Catholic imagery in modern art and on television (Beliefs column, May 16) is only a small sampling of the last bastion of tolerated bigotry in the United States. Such blatantly offensive incidents cannot be defended as artistic expression or disagreement with the Roman Catholic Church's teachings (letter, May 20).

Perhaps those who are indifferent to or amused by these public derisions of Christianity believe that Jesus' message of forgiveness and His directive to ''turn the other cheek'' somehow prohibit an outcry.
Or perhaps these people simply feel that Christianity's supposed majority status means that it is not, to borrow a term of the civil law, a ''protected class.'' Either way they are wrong.
(Rev.) THOMAS J. PAPROCKI Chancellor, Archdiocese of Chicago Chicago, May 20, 1998
